Copies student submission into student_dir and either precompiles it and returns the path to the precompiled submission or to the copied submission if no precompilation is necessary

pwd = temp/student_dir

async precompile_testcase(cli_args: str)#

Replaces the original testcase file with its compiled version, thus making reading its contents as plaintext harder. Useful in preventing cheating.

pwd = AutograderPaths.current_dir (i.e. the directory with all submissions)

prepend_test_helper()#

Prepends all of the associated test_helper code to test code

pwd = AutograderPaths.current_dir (i.e. the directory with all submissions)

stdout_testcase module#

class PathWithStdoutOnlyInfo(*args, picked_submission_type: Optional[Type[TestCase]] = None)#

Bases: PosixPath

This abomination is a hack to supply more info when running stdout only submissions. To prevent hacks like this, the architecture will need to be restructured to allow for things like stdout-only submissions.

I have a feeling we needed to focus on composition instead of inheritance (arguably) and implement a different grader class for stdout submissions (definitely).

picked_submission_type: Optional[Type[TestCase]]#
class StdoutOnlyTestCase(path: Path, timeout: float, weight: float, io: TestCaseIO, config: Mapping[str, Any], testcase_picker, prepend_test_helper: bool = True)#

Bases: TestCase

async compile_testcase(precompiled_submission: Path, cli_args: str)#

Compiles student submission and testcase into a single executable (or simply returns the command to run the testcase if no further compilation is necessary)

pwd = temp/student_dir

delete_executable_files(precompiled_submission: Path)#

We don’t compile each testcase separately so we don’t need to clean up executable files

delete_source_file(source_path: Path)#

There is no testcase file

classmethod is_a_type_of(path: Path, possible_source_file_stems: List[str], testcase_picker: TestCasePicker) → bool#
classmethod is_installed() → bool#

We assume all utilities necessary are installed because we can’t possibly check for all of them.

testcase_result_validator module#

generate_validating_string() → str#

Generates a string of pseudo-random ascii characters

validate_output(output: str, required_validating_string: str) → Tuple[str, float, bool]#

Checks if the output contains the correct validating string on the last line

Returns the output without the last line (or empty string if it was empty), the score that was printed with the validation string and boolean that is true if output is valid.
